histDist.name: Pennsylvania Avenue National Historic Site
histDist.description: Pennsylvania Avenue National Historic Site, a unit of National Mall and Memorial Parks. This unique site preserves locations related to the creation of the Federal City, Presidential Inaugurations, and historically significant events.
histDist.label: Pennsylvania Ave NHS

histDist.name: Massachusetts Avenue Historic District
histDist.description: Massachusetts Avenue Historic District includes approximately 150 buildings. Boulevard of grand mansioms, row houses, and embassies, known as Embassy Row.
histDist.label: Massachusetts Ave HD
histDist.address: Massachusetts Ave from 17th St, NW to Observatory Cir, NW

histDist.name: Fifteenth Street Financial Historic District
histDist.label: Fifteenth St. Financial HD
histDist.address: 15th St NW btwn Pennsylvania Ave and I St, NW

histDist.name: Seventeenth Street Historic District
histDist.label: Seventeenth St HD
histDist.address: Seventeenth St, NW, West Side between New York and Constitution Aves

histDist.name: Grant Road Historic District
histDist.description: The Grant Road Historic District is located in the North Cleveland Park neighborhood of Washington, D.C.. It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2004.
histDist.label: Grant Rd HD
histDist.address: Grant Road from Wisconsin Ave to Brandywide St, NW

histDist.name: Greater Fourteenth Street Historic District
histDist.description: The Greater Fourteenth Street and Logan Circle Historic District cover an area of about 24 city blocks bisected by 14th Street N.W. just north of Massachusetts Avenue and edge of downtown. The area includes more than 750 residential, commercial and religious buildings.
histDist.label: Greater 14th St HD
histDist.address: http://planning.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/op/publication/attachments/Fourteenth_Street_Historic_District_Map.pdf

histDist.name: Logan Circle Historic District
histDist.description: The Greater Fourteenth Street and Logan Circle Historic District cover an area of about 24 city blocks bisected by 14th Street N.W. just north of Massachusetts Avenue and edge of downtown. The area includes more than 750 residential, commercial and religious buildings.
histDist.label: Logan Circle HD
histDist.address: Logan Circle

histDist.name: Sixteenth Street Historic District
histDist.description: It is an impressive residential avenue lined with buildings reflecting a myriad of architectual styles. Many of the ornate townhouses and mansions that were its first adornments have been replaced by large office buildings and hotels.
histDist.label: Sixteenth St HD
histDist.address: The 16th Street Historic District includes buildings fronting on 16th St., NW, from Scott Circle to Florida Ave

histDist.name: Greater U Street Historic District
histDist.description: Greater U Street Historic District is currently a thriving residential and commercial neighborhood of north-west Washington.
histDist.label: Greater U St HD

histDist.name: Washington Cathedral and Close Historic District
histDist.description: Washington Cathedral is located in the Washington Cathedral and Close Historic District
histDist.label: Washington Cathedral HD
histDist.address: Wisconsin Avenue at Massachusetts Avenue, NW

histDist.name: McMillan Park Reservoir Historic District
histDist.description: The McMillan Park Reservoir Historic District consists of the McMillan Reservoir (built 1883-1888), which remains an integral part of the city's water supply system; the Sand Filtration Plant (1905), designed and built as the city's first water treatment facility; and McMillan Park, built 1908-1913.
histDist.label: McMillan Park Reservoir HD
histDist.address: 1st St & Michigan Ave, NW

histDist.name: Gallaudet College Historic District
histDist.description: Gallaudet College, the main college building was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1966 and designated a National Historic Landmark in 1965. The NRHP area was increased and named Gallaudet College Historic District in 1974
histDist.label: Gallaudet College HD
histDist.address: 7th St & Florida Ave, NE

histDist.name: Ford's Theatre National Historic Site
histDist.description: Ford's Theatre National Historic Site includes Ford's Theatre
histDist.label: Ford's Theatre NHS
histDist.address: 10th St, between E & F Sts, NW

histDist.name: Marine Barracks Historic District
histDist.description: Located on the corners of 8th & I Streets in southeast Washington, D.C., the Barracks supports both ceremonial and security missions in the nation's capital.
histDist.label: Marine Barracks HD
histDist.address: 750 8th St, SE

histDist.name: Saint Elizabeths Hospital Historic District
histDist.description: The campus of Saint Elizabeth Hospital is a National Historic Landmark that embodies a story of local and national significance.
histDist.label: St. Elizabeth's Hospital HD
histDist.address: 2700 Martin Luther King Jr. Ave, SE

histDist.name: Fort McNair (The Old Arsenal)
histDist.description: Fort McNair, Washington D.C. is a US Army operated military facility located in a small peninsula at the intersection of two rivers- Anacostia and Potomac.
histDist.label: Fort McNair
histDist.address: 4th & P Streets, SW

histDist.name: Soldier's Home National Historic Site
histDist.label: Soldier's Home NHS
histDist.address: Rock Creek Church Rd & Upshur St, NW

histDist.name: Armed Forces Retirement Home-Washington Historic District
histDist.description: The Armed Forces Retirement Home-Washington is a retirement home for retirees of the United States Armed Forces located in the Park View neighborhood of Washington, D.C. The complex forms an historic district that was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2007
histDist.label: Armed Forces Retirement Home HD

histDist.name: Washington Navy Yard Historic District
histDist.description: The historic district of the Washington Navy Yard was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1973.
histDist.label: Washington Navy Yard HD
histDist.address: 8th & M Sts, SE

histDist.name: Georgetown Visitation Convent and Preparatory School
histDist.description: Georgetown Visitation Preparatory School was founded in Washington, DC in 1799 as the Georgetown Academy for Young Ladies.
histDist.label: Georgetown Visitation Convent and Prep School
histDist.address: 1500 35th St, NW

histDist.name: Marjorie Webster Historic District
histDist.description: The Marjorie Webster Junior College meets National Register criteria A and C at the local level of significance.
histDist.label: Marjorie Webster HD
histDist.address: Area South of Kalmia and East of 17th St NW

histDist.name: Immaculata Seminary Historic District
histDist.description: Immaculata Seminary islocated in the Historic District.
histDist.label: Immaculata Seminary HD
histDist.address: 4340 Nebraska Avenue NW

histDist.name: Federal Triangle Historic District
histDist.description: Federal Triangle is occupied by 10 large city and federal office buildings, all of which are part of the Pennsylvania Avenue National Historic Site.
histDist.label: Federal Triangle HD
histDist.address: Between 15th Street, Constitution and Pennsylvania Avenues, NW and E street

histDist.name: Sheridan-Kalorama Historic District
histDist.description: Sheridan-Kalorama Historic District is comprised of a network of cohesive town-and suburbs-like residential streetscapes.
histDist.label: Sheridan-Kalorama HD
histDist.address: The Sheridan-Kalorama Historic District is located at the top of the Washington escarpment bound by Massachusetts Avenue on the southwest,  Connecticut Avenue on the east, and Rock Creek Park on the north

histDist.name: Shaw Historic District
histDist.description: Social organizations, shops, industrial enterprizes, schools, and churches have called Shaw home. Because of its unique developmental history and its architectural quality and diversity, Shaw was formally recognized by the city in 1999 with designation as a historic district.
histDist.label: Shaw HD

histDist.name: Mount Pleasant Historic District
histDist.description: Mount Pleasant Historic District includes approximately 1100 buildings. It is a residential district illustrating the growth and development of Washington D.C.'s first suburbs in its transition from rural to urban context.
histDist.label: Mt. Pleasant HD

histDist.name: Kalorama Triangle Historic District
histDist.description: The Kalorama Triangle Historic District includes 353 historic buildings. Almost exclusively residential incharacter, its curvilinear streets are filled with fine examples of late 19th and early 20th century urban dwellings and apartment buildings.
histDist.label: Kalorama Triangle HD

histDist.name: Blagden Alley/Naylor Court
histDist.label: Blagden Alley/Naylor Court HD
histDist.address: http://planning.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/op/publication/attachments/Blagden_Naylor_Historic_%2520District_%2520Map.pdf

histDist.name: Foggy Bottom Historic District
histDist.description: Historically, Foggy Bottom was divided into two sections, with 23rd Street, N.W. forming the boundary between an upper income neighborhood to the east and the working class/ industrial area to the west.
histDist.label: Foggy Bottom HD

histDist.name: Downtown Historic District
histDist.description: Downtown Washington is a guide for exploring the diverse collection of historic buildings located in Washington's commercial downtown. Within this larger downtown area are several recognized historic districts and sites: the Downtown Historic District, the Fifteen's Street Historic District and Pennsylvania Avenue National Historic District.
histDist.label: Downtown HD

histDist.name: Cleveland Park Historic District
histDist.description: Served by a metro stop, the neighborhood contains a cohesive collection of single-family residences, apartment buildings, a vibrant commercial corridor with stores and restaurants, schools,a library, fire station and other amenities.
histDist.label: Cleveland Park HD
histDist.address: Woodley Rd, Wisconsin Ave, Tilden St, and Connecticut Ave, NW

histDist.name: Anacostia Historic District
histDist.description: East of the Anacostia River, in sight of the U.S. Capitol, lies an area of unusual natural beauty and rich heritage.
histDist.label: Anacostia HD
histDist.address: http://planning.dc.gov/sites/default/files/dc/sites/op/publication/attachments/Anacostia_Historic_Brochure_0.pdf

histDist.name: Woodley Park Historic District
histDist.description: This residential district with commercial corridor maintains a strong connection to its past and conveys a sense of history through its carefully planned streets, historic architecture, and open space.
histDist.label: Woodley Park HD
histDist.address: Rock Creek Park, Calvert St, Woodley Rd, and Cathedral Ave, NW

histDist.name: Takoma Park Historic District
histDist.description: Takoma Park Historic District includes approximately 160 religious, educational, and commercial insitutions.
histDist.label: Takoma Park HD

histDist.name: Mount Vernon Triangle Historic District
histDist.description: Although there are other buildings in the Triangle, the historic district provides the most cohesive collection of buildings that together tell the story of the larger area.
histDist.label: Mount Vernon Triangle HD

histDist.name: Washington Heights Historic District
histDist.description: Located in the heart of the Adam Morgan neighborhood, the Washington Heights HD contains one of the finest collections of architecture in DC from19th century rowhouses and early 20th century luxury apartments to flourishing commercial corridor, the development of Washington Heights is a thriving urban center.
histDist.label: Washington Heights HD
histDist.address: Bounded by Florida Ave. Washington Hilton, Columbia Rd., and rear of 18th St, NW

histDist.name: Strivers' Section Historic District
histDist.description: Strivers' Section Historic District is a compact residential enclave of rowhouses and small apartment buildings.
histDist.label: Strivers' Section HD
histDist.address: Swann St, Florida Ave, Sixteenth St Historic District

histDist.name: Dupont Circle Historic District
histDist.description: One of the city's most elegant historic residential neighborhoods. Notable for superior examples of Victorian rowhouse architecture in Queen Anne and Richardsonian styles, as well as some of the city's fines turn-of-the-century mansions in Beaux Arts, Chateauesque, Renaissance, and Georgian Revival styles.
histDist.label: Dupont Circle HD

histDist.name: Foxhall Historic District
histDist.description: Modelled after an old English Village, Foxhall is a Tudor Revival-style rowhouse neighborhood located in Northwest DC. Foxhall Village is one of the city's only large-scale residential development to have been realized in such a manner.
histDist.label: Foxhall HD
histDist.address: Reservoir Road, Glover-Archibald Park, P Street NW, Foxhall Road

histDist.name: Mount Vernon Square Historic District
histDist.description: Mount Vernon Square Historic District is a commercial and residenial neighborhood located within the historic boundaries of the District of Columbia's Federal City. The historic district covers the area that includes twelve city blocks in North West DC. Area includes approximately 420 properties.
histDist.label: Mt. Vernon Square HD
histDist.address: 1st Street, New York Avenue, 7th Street, and M and N Streets, NW

histDist.name: Capitol Hill Historic District
histDist.description: The Capitol Hill Historic District is one of the oldest residential neighborhoods of Washington D.C. The district, which includes 200 city squares and approximately 8,000 buildings, is one of the largest historic districts in the country.
histDist.label: Capitol Hill HD

histDist.name: Georgetown Historic District
histDist.description: Designated a National Historic Landmark in 1967, the Georgetown Historic District is included in the D.C. Inventory of historic places and listed in the national register of historic places.
histDist.label: Georgetown HD

histDist.name: LeDroit Park Historic District
histDist.description: LeDroit Park Historic District is a 42.6 acre site that includes approximately 100 buildings. The historic District is an early example of a planned, architecturally unified suburban subdivision.
histDist.label: LeDroit Park HD

histDist.name: Meridian Hill Historic District
histDist.description: Meridian Hill Park is a structured urban park located in the Washington, D.C neighborhood of Columbia Heights; it abuts the nearby neighborhood of Adams Morgan. The park was designed and built between 1912 and 1940.
histDist.label: Meridian Hill
histDist.address: Meridian Hill

histDist.name: Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park
histDist.description: The C&O Canal follows the route of the Potomac River for 184.5 miles from Washington, D.C. to Cumberland, MD.
histDist.label: C & O Canal NHP
histDist.address: Along C&O Canal from Rock Creek to D.C. boundary

histDist.name: Lafayette Square Historic District
histDist.description: Lafayette Square Historic District is a historic district in Washington, D.C.. It includes the 7-acre. Lafayette Square park, and surrounding buildings. It is part of President's Park.
histDist.label: Lafayette Square HD

histDist.name: Rock Creek Park Historic District
histDist.description: Rock Creek Park is a large urban park that bisects the Northwest quadrant of Washington, D.C.
histDist.label: Rock Creek Park HD

histDist.name: Glover-Archbold Park (Res 450 & 351)
histDist.description: Glover-Archbold Park is a stream valley park, Northwest, Washington, D.C., on the western edge of the Glover Park neighborhood. It includes Foundry Branch from Van Ness Street, to Canal Road, on the Potomac River.
histDist.label: Glover-Archbold Park
histDist.address: Glover-Archbold Park

histDist.name: East and West Potomac Parks Historic District
histDist.description: East and West Potomac Parks Historic District is a U.S. national park in Washington, D.C., adjacent to the National Mall. It includes the parkland that extends south of the Lincoln Memorial Reflecting Pool, from the Lincoln Memorial to the grounds of the Washington Monument.
histDist.label: East & West Potomac Parks HD
histDist.address: Along Potomac River from Constitution Avenue to Hains Point

histDist.name: National Zoological Park
histDist.description: The National Zoological Park, commonly known as the National Zoo, is one of the oldest zoos in the United States, and as part of the Smithsonian Institution.
histDist.label: National Zoological Park HD
histDist.address: 3001 Connecticut Ave, NW

histDist.name: National Mall
histDist.description: Officially established in 1965, National Mall and Memorial Parks contains some of the oldest protected park lands in the National Park Service.
histDist.label: National Mall HD

histDist.name: National Arboretum
histDist.description: A 446-acre living museum 2 miles from the Capitol: gardens, collections, bonsai museum, herb garden, azaleas, flowering cherry trees, and the original columns from the Capitol. - See more at: http://washington.org/find-dc-listings/national-arboretum#sthash.SEUD1Xxu.dpuf
histDist.label: National Arboretum
histDist.address: 3501 New York Ave, NE

histDist.name: Theodore Roosevelt Island National Memorial (Analostan Island)
histDist.description: Theodore Roosevelt Island is a 88.5-acre island and a national memorial located in the Potomac River in Washington, D.C.
histDist.label: T.R. Island Nat'l Mem.
histDist.address: Potomac River west of Georgetown Channel

histDist.name: Potomac Gorge, The (Potomac Palisades)
histDist.description: The neighborhood has long been home to an eclectic mix of artists, writers, government workers and environmentalists.
histDist.label: The Potomac Gorge
histDist.address: Potomac River upstream from Key Bridge

histDist.name: Rock Creek & Potomac Parkway (Res 360)
histDist.description: Rock Creek & Potomac Parkway is a parkway maintained by the National Park Service as part of Rock Creek Park in Washington, D.C.
histDist.label: Rock Creek & Potomac Pkwy.
histDist.address: Rock Creek & Potomac Parkway (from Lincoln Memorial to Nat'l Zoo)

histDist.name: Montrose Park (Res 324)
histDist.description: Montrose Park is a massive piece of countryside right in the middle of the city
histDist.label: Montrose Park
histDist.address: R St, NW

histDist.name: Dumbarton Oaks Park (Res 637)
histDist.description: Dumbarton Oaks Park is a milestone in the history of American landscape architecture and a landmark in our social history, as it represents the finest work of Beatrix Farrand
histDist.label: Dumbarton Oaks Park
histDist.address: 32nd & R St, NW

histDist.name: Greystone Enclave
histDist.label: Greystone Enclave
histDist.address: Area between Beach Drive and Williamsburg LN NW

histDist.name: Fort Circle Parks Historic District
histDist.description: The historic features are collectively known as the Civil War Defenses of Washington, or the Fort Circle Parks.
histDist.label: Fort Circle Parks
histDist.address: Around DC
